definition:
Let $S_n$ be the $n^\mathrm{th}$ partial sum of the series
$a_1\!+\!a_2\!+\cdots$ with real or complex $a_n$
($n = 1,\,2,\,\ldots$).

-   If the series is convergent with sum $S$, then we call the
    $R_n := S\!-\!S_n$ the $n^\mathrm{th}$ [*remainder term*]{} or
    simply [*remainder*]{} of the series ($n = 1,\,2,\,\ldots$). Then
    $\lim_{n\to\infty}R_n = 0$.

-   If there exists a number $s$ such that
    $\lim_{n\to\infty}(s\!-\!S_n) = 0$, then the series is convergent
    and its sum is $s$.
